w:r.w:t: 10g : sql tuning advisor. unfortunately manual process, and disconnected from ADDM.
The Optimizer now runs in 2 modes. First is the normal mode. when you execute an
sql the Optimizer generates a plan for that statement.
The Optimizer now runs in 2 distinct modes :
The optimizer compiles the SQL and generates an execution plan. Under normal mode, the optimizer operates with very strict time constraints, usually a fraction of a second
In Tuning Mode the optimizer will look at SQL statements that run in the system historically, and analyzes

them to determine if tuning recommendations can be generated. The optimizer performs additional analysis to check whether it can further improve the plan produced in normal mode. The optimizer output is not an

execution plan, but a series of actions, along with their rationale and expected benefit for producing a significantly better plan. When running in tuning mode, the optimizer is known as the Automatic Tuning Optimizer
The result of this tuning exercise will be a profile.
Automatic Tuning Optimizer is meant for complex and high-load SQL statements that have nontrivial impact on the database
Where do the SQL statements comes from?
(ADDM) proactively identifies high-load SQL statements that are good candidates for SQL tuning The
feature also automatically identifies problematic SQL statements
When are the SQL statements tuned?
The tuning is done during the system maintenance window as an Automated Task, and will run by default for only
identify SQL candidates for tuning from the AWR
tune each SQL statement by calling SQL tuning Advisor and generating a resulting profile
Test the SQL profiles generated by executing the SQL statement. Determine if the profile generated
Implement the SQL profiles if they meet the accepted implementation criteria.
What is done during Automatic SQL Tuning ?
The Automatic Tuning Optimizer performs the following types of tuning analysis:
The Automatic Tuning Optimizer checks each query object for missing or stale statistic
A SQL profile is a set of auxiliary information specific to a SQL statement
Automatic Tuning Optimizer explores whether a new index can significantly enhance query performance
Automatic Tuning Optimizer identifies common problems with the structure of SQL
statements that can lead to poor performance. These could be syntactic, semantic, or design problems
While tuning a SQL statement, SQL Tuning Advisor searches real-time and historical
performance data for alternative execution plans for the statement. If plans other than
the original plan exist, then SQL Tuning Advisor reports
SQL Tuning Advisor only recommends an alternative plan if the elapsed time of the
original plan is worse than alternative plan
Managing the Automatic SQL Tuning Advisor
The database can automatically tune SQL statements by identifying problematic
statements and implementing recommendations using SQL Tuning Advisor during
system maintenance windows. When run automatically, SQL Tuning Advisor is
Oracle Database automatically runs SQL Tuning Advisor on selected high-load SQL
statements from the Automatic Workload Repository (AWR) that qualify as tuning
windows on a nightly basis. By default,
hour. You can customize attributes of the maintenance windows, including start and
end time, frequency, and days of the week
The SQL Tuning Advisor is executed automatically during the scheduled maintenance
window on those SQL statements, and SQL baseline Profiles are created.
To identify which SQL statements the AWR is used.
After automatic SQL tuning begins, the database performs the following steps:
Identifies SQL candidates in the AWR for tuning
The database orders the SQL statements that are selected as candidates based on
their performance impact. The database calculates the impact by summing the
CPU time and the I/O times in AWR for the selected statement in the past week
The 'top' queries from the previous week, in 4 buckets :
top queries for the past week
top queries for any day in the past week
top queries by average single execution
statements tuned within the last month
SQL statements with performance problems caused by concurrency issues
Tunes each SQL statement individually by calling SQL Tuning Advisor
During the tuning process, the database considers and reports all recommendation
types, but it can implement only SQL profiles automatically.
Tests SQL profiles by executing the SQL statement
If a SQL profile is recommended, the database tests the new profile by executing
the SQL statement both with and without the profile. If the performance
improvement improves at least threefold, then the database accepts the SQL
profile, but only if the ACCEPT_SQL_PROFILES task parameter is set to TRUE
Optionally, implements the SQL profiles provided they meet the criteria of
The DBA_SQL_PROFILES column STATUS will be set to AUTO-TUNE if the SQL Tuning process created them.
Click on the Advisor Central link.
you can also enable or disable it. From the configure page which takes you to the
Automated Maintenance Tasks Configuration page. You can also choose which day you want the
Automatic SQL Tuning to be run.
Enabling and Disabling Automatic SQL Management
Automatic SQL tuning runs as part of the

Starting with Oracle Database 11g Release 2 (11.2.0.2), you can use the DBMS_AUTO_SQLTUNE package to configure the behavior of the automatic SQL tuning task.
For previous releases, use DBMS_SQLTUNE instead.
Starting with Oracle Database 11g Release 2 (11.2.0.2), you can use the DBMS_AUTO_SQLTUNE.REPORT_AUTO_TUNING_TASK function to generate the automatic SQL tuning
For previous releases, use the DBMS_SQLTUNE package instead
Tuning Reactively with SQL Tuning Advisor
You can invoke SQL Tuning Advisor manually for on-demand tuning of one or more
To tune multiple statements, you must create a SQL tuning set (STS).
A SQL tuning set is a database object that stores SQL statements along with their execution context
SQL Tuning Advisor provides options to manage the scope and duration of a tuning
task. You can set the scope of a tuning task either of the following:
In this case, SQL Tuning Advisor produces recommendations based on statistical
checks, access path analysis, and SQL structure analysis. SQL profile
In this case, SQL Tuning Advisor carries out all the analysis it performs under
limited scope plus SQL Profiling. With the comprehensive option you can also
specify a time limit for the tuning task, which by default is 30 minutes.
Whenever possible, run SQL Tuning Advisor using Enterprise Manager, as described
in the Oracle Database 2 Day + Performance Tuning Guide
You can create a SQL tuning task for a single SQL statement. For tuning multiple
statements, a SQL tuning set (STS) has to be first created.
You can create tuning tasks from the text of a single SQL statement, a SQL tuning set
containing multiple statements, a SQL statement selected by SQL identifier from the
shared SQL area, or a SQL statement selected by SQL identifier from AWR.
You must be granted the ADVISOR privilege.
Table 17â€“2 lists parameters that you can configure using the SET_TUNING_TASK_
Checking the Status of a SQL Tuning Task
You can check the status of the task by reviewing the information in the USER_ADVISOR_TASKS view or check execution progress of the task in the V$SESSION_LONGOPS.
For example, run the following query:
Checking the Progress of SQL Tuning Advisor
You can check the execution progress of SQL Tuning Advisor in the V$ADVISOR_PROGRESS view.
Displaying the Results of a SQL Tuning Task
After a task has been executed, you display a report of the results with the REPORT_TUNING_TASK function.
DBA_ADVISOR_TASKS - provides a parent record for each advisor task.
SQL tuning information views, such as DBA_SQLTUNE_STATISTICS, DBA_SQLTUNE_
